newsitem.title: GERMANY: Top Waigel ally doesn't see Italy in EMU -magazine.
newsitem.headline: Top Waigel ally doesn't see Italy in EMU -magazine.

text.p: A leading ally of German Finance Minister Theo Waigel said in a paper to be presented to a party meeting that he cannot imagine Italy joining the first wave of European monetary union, Focus magazine reported on Saturday.

Michael Glos, parliamentary leader of Waigel's Christian Social Union (CSU), said in the discussion paper that "I cannot imagine a currency union with Italy", Focus reported in an advance release of Monday's edition.
"Financial quality is more important that quantitative mass," Glos is quoted as writing.
Party sources confirmed that the quotations from the discussion paper reflected Glos's views.

Glos wrote that the stability of the new currency, the euro, was more important than wishful foreign policy preferences, and said Spain and Belgium should also not be admitted to monetary union on January 1, 1999, according to Focus.
The paper is intended to be presented to the CSU's traditional three-day winter leadership conference in Wildbad Kreuth, beginning on Wednesday.
The CSU is the conservative Bavarian-based sister party of Chancellor Helmut Kohl's Christian Democrats, and a junior partner in the Bonn coalition.
